awd_titl_txt: Automated Discovery of Content-in-Context Relationships from a Large Corpus of Arctic Social Science Data
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is for an Early Concept Grant for Exploratory Research (EAGER) project research a potentially transformative approach to information management and knowledge discovery.  The research will develop an approach to searching social science data (handwritten notes, analog and digital video, photos, and audio records, maps, illustrations, etc.) without associated metadata.   The approach will be tested on a unique document collection generated from the Exchange for Local Observations and Knowledge of the Arctic (ELOKA), originally funded by the National Science Foundation during the International Polar Year 2007-2008. 

Leveraging inherent structures and boundary conditions among embedded levels of granularity in a digital resource collection (i.e., automated granularity), this project on Automated Discovery of Content-in-Context Relationships from a Large Corpus of Arctic Social Science Data has three objectives: (1) manage a document collection without metadata or databases: (2) generate relational schema without metadata or databases; and (3) analyze efficiencies and functionalities of automated granularity relative to metadata and database solutions.  Files in Portable Document Format (PDF), which is a classic type of unstructured data, will be used to generate content-in-context relationships (i.e, relational schema) objectively and simply from the inherent structure of the documents.

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF COLORADO

por.por_cntn:
This award was for an Early Concept Grant for Exploratory Research (EAGER) project to research a potentially transformative approach for information management and knowledge discovery, applying the inherent structure of digital information automatically and objectively in the cloud. The research further developed an approach to search social science data (handwritten notes, analog and digital video, photos, and audio records, maps, illustrations, etc.) without the need for some elements of manually created metadata.  Leveraging inherent structures and boundary conditions among embedded levels of granularity in a digital resource collection (i.e., automated granularity), this project on "Automated Discovery of Content-in-Context Relationships from a Large Corpus of Arctic Social Science Data" had three objectives: (1) manage a document collection without some elements of metadata or structured databases: (2) generate relational schema without some elements of metadata or structured databases; and (3) analyze efficiencies and functionalities of automated granularity relative to metadata and database solutions. Files in Portable Document Format (PDF), which is a classic type of unstructured data, were used to generate content-in-context relationships (i.e., relational schema) objectively and simply from the inherent structure of the documents.

The approach was tested on a number of document collection generated from several programs and projects including the: Exchange for The Arctic Council; Polar Data Forum, Exchange for Local Observations and Knowledge of the Arctic (ELOKA); and Arctic/Pan-Arctic Options projects supported by the National Science Foundation regarding Holistic Integration for Arctic Coastal-Marine Sustainability.  The most recent application example with KnoHowTM is the integration of 35 chapters in Building Common Interests in the Arctic Ocean with Global Inclusion. Volume 2. Informed Decisionmaking for Sustainability (Springer, in press), which is elaborated in the Introduction and Conclusions. 

Additionally, KnoHowTM was applied in the video-conferencing courses in Spring 2020 (Science Diplomacy: Environmental Security and Law in the Arctic Ocean) in Spring 2021 (Science Diplomacy and International Law) with students integrating their own PDF collections on the portal (https://knohow.co), as introduced with the knowledge bank of Arctic Council Ministerial Declarations that has been updated biennially with Arctic Council Ministerial Meetings since 2013. Using new "GeoParsing" functionality (ability to extract and locate text references using place names) KnoHowTM was used to teach the student how to extract geographic information from unstructured data and then linking this information to other concepts in structured databases in Geographic Information Systems (Cartographic Theory and Design, third year undergraduate course). 

At a fundamental level, mechanisms for deploying, maintaining, and further developing KnoHow? computer sources code were greatly improved.  KnoHowTM now can be easily deployed, managed and enhanced on cloud-based systems like Amazon Web Services.  This functionality provides the basis for rapid development with unique applications for information management and knowledge discovery that are scalable.


Last Modified: 11/25/2021
Modified by: Peter L Pulsifer
